docblock.description: Represents an exception during upload.
docblock.long-description: Occurs when the *server* had a problem, or the *client* appears to be attempting to bypass the normal PHP file upload safeguards.

docblock.description: A specific kind of UploadException: the server had a problem.

tag.name: var
tag.description: The HTML name we were given.

docblock.description: Return the message specific for this exception code.
Returns a string containing deeper diagnostics of the system state at the time the server problem occurred.
docblock.long-description:
Server problems may not last long (a lot of simultaneous uploads temporarily eats all the upload space) or may be semi-permanent (an extension is preventing all uploads). It's therefore important to know as much as possible about the system at the time of the problem.
This method captures the free space available, loaded extensions, and session id into a string for foresnic diagnostics.

tag.description: All IP addresses reported by proxy headers, with the last- most element being the proxy IP address itself.

docblock.description: Implements the Y-combinator.

tag.name: TODO
tag.description: The recursive callable which we pass to the Y-combinator has exponential run-time. But, we can change that to linear time just by adding caching to the internal combinator. That's where this class comes in: it internally caches intermediary results, so that simple recursive definitions have optimal performance without having to implement their own caching.

docblock.description: A specific kind of UploadException: the upload is suspicious.

docblock.description: Return the message specific for this exception code.
Returns a string containing details of the remote connection at the time the security concern was raised.
docblock.long-description:
Knowing the remote connection and environment helps frame the context of the problem: patterns of attack, duration, payload sizes. From this data, you can better adapt your environment.
This method captures the session ID, IP address, and other environment details into a string for foresnic diagnostics.

docblock.description: Accessor methods for the HTML name of a file upload.
docblock.long-description:
Every uploaded file has a name, given to it in the HTML form. The HTML spec says the name qualifies as CDATA, so pretty much any character can comprise an HTML variable name. However, the HTML name we have access to is subject to PHP engine rules' name mangling.
In many cases, the HTML name returned matches the HTML name given, but not in all cases:
Given in Form |Returned from getHtmlName() |Match? ------------------|------------------------------|------ foo |foo |Yes foo[bar] |foo[bar] |Yes foo[bar][baz_1] |foo[bar][baz_1] |Yes foo_bar |foo_bar |Yes foo.bar |foo_bar |No foo bar |foo_bar |No foo[] |foo[0] |No
As a rule of thumb, avoid using "." and " " in your HTML form names. When using array syntax, prefer explicit naming your keys.

tag.name: var
tag.description: The HTML name we were given.

docblock.description: Get the HTML variable name.

docblock.description: Represents a file that did not successfully upload.
docblock.long-description: Errors occur when the *client* did something wrong. The possible causes are: - The client did not upload a file. - The client uploaded a partial, incomplete file. - The client sent more bytes than either the form or the server allowed.

tag.name: see
tag.description: which occurs when the server went wrong or the client appears to be circumventing PHP file upload safeguards.

tag.name: var
tag.description: The error code.

tag.name: var
tag.description: The size of the file uploaded.

property.name: $messages
property.default: array(UPLOAD_ERR_INI_SIZE => 'The file size exceeds the server-allowed limit.', UPLOAD_ERR_FORM_SIZE => 'The file size exceeds the form-allowed upload limit.', UPLOAD_ERR_PARTIAL => 'The file was only partially uploaded.', UPLOAD_ERR_NO_FILE => 'No file was uploaded.')

docblock.description: The possible failure codes and an English description.

tag.name: var
tag.description: The HTML name we were given.

docblock.description: Change the text associated with a PHP upload error code.
docblock.long-description:
You may want to localize or otherwise change the generic error associated with one of the upload error codes. You may only change messages for the following upload error codes:
- UPLOAD_ERR_INI_SIZE (1) : The upload exceeds the `upload_max_filesize` directive. - UPLOAD_ERR_FORM_SIZE (2) : The upload exceeds the `MAX_FILE_SIZE` directive in the HTML form. - UPLOAD_ERR_PARTIAL (3) : The upload was incomplete. - UPLOAD_ERR_NO_FILE (4) : No file was uploaded.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The code whose message you want to change.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The new message for that code.

tag.name: throws
tag.description: If the given code does not have a message

docblock.description: Return a description of why the error occurred.

tag.name: see
tag.description: To adjust the message globally.

docblock.description: Is the error because the uploaded file was too big?
docblock.long-description: An upload may exceed either the `upload_max_filesize` setting or the `MAX_FILE_SIZE` input. This method handles both cases and returns true if either of these limits was reached. In such a case, the optional pass-by-reference `$maximum` will indicate the maximum possible size.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The server or form allowed maximum file size, in bytes.

docblock.description: Is the error because the uploaded file was only partially received?

tag.name: param
tag.description: The number of bytes received.

docblock.description: Is the error because no file was uploaded?
Get the HTML variable name.

parse_markers.error: No summary was found for this file

docblock.description: Return information about the upload configuration.
docblock.long-description: Some values come directly from the PHP configuration. Others are calculated using the PHP configuration and run-time information.

docblock.description: Are file uploads enabled?
docblock.long-description: Specified at the system level by the `file_uploads` ini directive.

docblock.description: In what directory will uploads be held for processing?
docblock.long-description: Specified at the system level by the `upload_tmp_dir` ini directive. If that directory isn't writeable, then PHP falls back to the system temporary directory, which is specified at the system level by the `sys_temp_dir` ini directive (and we can just ask `sys_get_temp_dir`).

docblock.description: What is the maximum file size supported system-wide?
docblock.long-description:
Controlled by the system-level directive `upload_max_filesize`, but also constrained by the system-level directive `post_max_size`. The *lower* of the two values defines the *upper* limit of the maximum file size.
If the number of returned bytes equals `PHP_INT_MAX`, there is effectively no limit.

docblock.description: What is the maximum file size reported for the submitted form?
docblock.long-description:
If you include a hidden input element named `MAX_FILE_SIZE` in your form, then all file inputs that come *after* that hidden input element will be limited to the number of bytes given in the `MAX_FILE_SIZE`.
If the number of returned bytes equals `PHP_INT_MAX`, there is effectively no limit.

docblock.description: How many simultaneous file uploads do we support?
docblock.long-description: If the number of returned uploads equals `PHP_INT_MAX`, there is effectively no limit.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Number of uploads

docblock.description: Given two values which follow the "0 or fewer is unlimited" pattern, return the limiting number or PHP_INT_MAX if neither would limit.

No summary for function \Haldayne\Boost\bytes()

docblock.description: `int ini_size_to_bytes(string)` - Convert a short-hand bytes specification into integer bytes.
docblock.long-description:
Some PHP ini values (like `upload_max_filesize`) allow you to specify the number of bytes in a short-hand, like "10M" or "1G". But, when you call `ini_get` you'll get these actual short-hand values, instead of the byte equivalent (which usually you want).
This function converts a super-set of documented short-hand into bytes: * An optional leading + * Number specification in hex, octal, or decimal * Kilo-, Mega-, Giga-, and Tera-bytes expressed using single or double characters in either lower or upper case: "k", "kB", "G", "Pb", etc.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A value from an ini_get call to process

tag.name: return
tag.description: Number of bytes the short-hand string represents

tag.name: see
tag.description: Documents the short-hand

parse_markers.error: No summary was found for this file

docblock.description: Return the IPv4 or v6 address of the connecting client.
docblock.long-description:
The connecting client might be a proxy. If you care to know the IP of the client using the proxy, you must rely upon proxy-provided headers: **which can be spoofed**.
If you want a reliable IP that may not uniquely represent the actual connecting client, use this function. But if you want a less reliable, though often more accurate proxy-client IP address, use the `header_ip` function.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The connecting client IP, up to 45 ASCII characters long or null if using the CLI SAPI.

parse_markers.error: No summary was found for this file

docblock.description: An improvement on PHP associative arrays.
docblock.long-description:
Sports a fluent interface accepting callables to drive array operations, similar in spirit to jQuery. Supports keys of any type: scalars, even arrays and objects! Used in place of `array ()` and `[]`, your code will be easier to write *and* read.
In the API, a formal variable named `$collection` must be one of: - Haldayne\Boost\Map - Haldayne\Boost\Contract\Arrayable - Haldayne\Boost\Contract\Jsonable - \Traversable - object - array
Many of these methods allow you to apply code to all elements of the map: look for formal parameters named `$code` or `$expression`. Some will allow `callable`, which are the usual PHP callable types. Some will allow for both `callable` *and* `string`.
When given as string, an anonymous function is built for you, using the string as the meat of the function. This lets you write extremely compact expressions for filtering, at the one-time cost of converting the string to the body of an anonymous function. Inside these anonymous functions the variable `$_0` holds the current value, while $_1 holds the current key.
In the API, a formal variable named `$key` may be of *any* type.
As much as possible, method names were chosen to reflect synonymous usage in the PHP engine itself. When not possible or relevant, the names may reflect usage from Laravel.

docblock.description: Should the comparison be made loosely?
Should the comparison be made strictly?
The internal array representation of the map.
The guard code protecting sets.
Track hashes we've created for non-string keys.
Create a new map.
docblock.long-description: Initialize the map with the given collection, if any. Accepts any kind of collection: array, object, Traversable, another Map, etc. Optionally, wrap every key,value sets into the map with the given guard code: if the guard code fails, the set will throw an exception.

docblock.description: Return a new map containing only members of this map that pass the expression.
Return a new map containing the first N elements passing the expression.
docblock.long-description:
Like `find`, but stop after finding N elements from the front. Defaults to N = 1.
``` $nums = new Map(range(0, 9)); $odd3 = $nums->first('1 == ($_0 % 2)', 3); // first three odds ```

docblock.description: Return a new map containing the last N elements passing the expression.
docblock.long-description:
Like `first`, but stop after finding N elements from the *end*. Defaults to N = 1.
``` $nums = new Map(range(0, 9)); $odds = $nums->last('1 == ($_0 % 2)', 2); // last two odd numbers ```

docblock.description: Test if every element passes the expression.
Test if at least one element passes the expression.
Test that no elements pass the expression.
Determine if a key exists the map.
docblock.long-description: This is the object method equivalent of the magic isset($map[$key]);

docblock.description: Get the value corresponding to the given key.
docblock.long-description:
If the key does not exist in the map, return the default.
This is the object method equivalent of the magic $map[$key].

docblock.description: Set a key and its corresponding value into the map.
docblock.long-description: This is the object method equivalent of the magic $map[$key] = 'foo'.

tag.name: fluent
tag.description: This method is part of a fluent interface and will return the same instance

docblock.description: Remove a key and its corresponding value from the map.
docblock.long-description: This is the object method equivalent of the magic unset($map[$key]);

tag.name: fluent
tag.description: This method is part of a fluent interface and will return the same instance

docblock.description: Determine if any key and their values have been set into the map.
Return a new map containing those keys and values that are not present in the given collection.
docblock.long-description: If comparison is loose, then only those elements whose values match will be removed. Otherwise, comparison is strict, and elements whose keys and values match will be removed.

docblock.description: Return a new map containing those keys and values that are present in the given collection.
docblock.long-description: If comparison is loose, then only those elements whose value match will be included. Otherise, comparison is strict, and elements whose keys & values match will be included.

docblock.description: Execute the given code over each element of the map. The code receives the value and then the key as formal parameters.
docblock.long-description:
The items are walked in the order they exist in the map. If the code returns boolean false, then the iteration halts. Values can be modified from within the callback, but not keys.
Example: ``` $map->each(function (&$value, $key) { $value++; return true; })->sum(); ```

tag.name: fluent
tag.description: This method is part of a fluent interface and will return the same instance

docblock.description: Like `walk`, except walk from the end toward the front.

tag.name: fluent
tag.description: This method is part of a fluent interface and will return the same instance

docblock.description: Groups elements of this map based on the result of an expression.
Treat the map as a stack and push an element onto its end.

tag.name: fluent
tag.description: This method is part of a fluent interface and will return the same instance

Count the number of items in the map.
Copy this map into an array, recursing as necessary to convert contained collections into arrays.
Return a JSON representation of the object.
Determine if a value exists at a given key.
Get a value at a given key.
Set the value at a given key.
docblock.long-description: If key is null, the value is appended to the array using numeric indexes. If the map was constructed with a set guard, then pass the value to the guard. If the guard fails, the set throws an exception.

docblock.description: Unset the value at a given key.
Get an iterator for a copy of the map.
Give me a native PHP array, regardless of what kind of collection-like structure is given.
Calls the given code with the given value and key as first & second argument.
Decide if the given value is considered "passing" or "failing".
Lookup the hash for the given key. If a hash does not yet exist, one is created.
Lookup the key for the given hash.
Finds elements for which the given code passes, optionally limited to a maximum count.

docblock.description: Manufactures a lambda from a string.
Creates a callable returning the given expression.
docblock.long-description:
If the expression is already callable, returns it untouched. If the expression is a string, a closure will be wrapped around the string returning it as a single line. In this case, the first nine positional arguments are available as $_0, $_1, ..., $_9.
``` $lt = new Expression('$_0 < $_1'); var_dump($lt(0, 1)); // true var_dump($lt(1, 0)); // false var_dump($lt()); // false (null not less than null) var_dump($lt(-1)); // true (-1 is less than null) ```

tag.name: throws
tag.description: When $expression not of expected type

docblock.description: Get the callable manufactured for this expression.
